node.title: Scientists identify armoured dinosaur with tail like Aztec weapon
node.alt: The newly identified Cretaceous Period armored dinosaur Stegouros elengassen
node.description: The Stegouros elengassen is a four-legged creature which lived in what is now South America's southernmost tipÂ during the Cretaceous Period.
node.content:
["More than half a millennium ago, Aztec warriors brandished a weapon called a macuahuitl, a wooden club with jagged obsidian blades embedded on its sides, to inflict gruesome injuries on enemies in close combat.", "A newly identified armoured dinosaur that inhabited the Patagonian region of Chile did much the same thing to ward off predators about 74 million years ago with a tail resembling a macuahuitl, scientists said on Wednesday.", "The four-legged, plant-eating creature, named Stegouros elengassen, exemplifies the arms race that unfolded during the age of dinosaurs to acquire new traits to survive in a perilous world.", "It also sheds light on the evolution of a highly successful group of tank-like dinosaurs called ankylosaurs.", "The Stegouros lived in what is now South America's southernmost tip during the Cretaceous period in the twilight of the dinosaur era.", "It was small relative to other armoured dinosaurs, at about two\u00a0metres\u00a0long.", "The Stegouros had a beak-like mouth for cropping plants. Its back and sides were studded with bony structures called osteoderms that served as a coat of armour.", "Its tail was unique among dinosaurs. It was\u00a0relatively short with fewer vertebrae than other armoured dinosaurs.", "", "
The creature's tail is similar to an Aztec weapon called the\u00a0macuahuitl.(Reuters:\u00a0Fundacion Azara)
", "The tail's back half was covered by a frond-like structure composed of seven pairs of flattened, fused, bony elements with craggy edges sticking outward.", "\"For now, we can only imagine how might Stegouros have used this weapon \u2014\u00a0and tail-swinging side to side as self-defence mechanism is a good guess,\" said vertebrate palaeontologist Sergio Soto, a University of Chile doctoral student and lead author of the study published in the journal Nature.", "\"The macuahuitl was an Aztec war club used in close combat by Aztec warriors, probably in a similar way to a sword, causing massive damage to the opponent. The tail weapon of Stegouros roughly resembles a macuahuitl,\" study co-author and University of Chile vertebrate palaeontologist Alexander Vargas added.", "Stegouros was smaller than ankylosaurs from the northern hemisphere such as Ankylosaurus, which reached eight\u00a0metres\u00a0long.", "Ankylosaurs, some possessing blunt bony clubs at the end of their tails, are closely related to an earlier group of armoured dinosaurs called stegosaurs whose tail weaponry came in the form of a structure of paired spikes called a thagomizer.", "The tail of Stegouros differed from both.", "\"Uncovering a new type of tail weaponry in armoured dinosaurs was a huge surprise for our team. When you imagine discovering a new type of armoured dinosaur, you do not expect to find a morphology so dissimilar to those already known,\" Mr\u00a0Soto said.", "Stegouros lived alongside four-legged, long-necked dinosaurs, two-legged carnivorous dinosaurs, turtles, frogs and small mammals by the banks of meandering rivers.", "The nearly complete and well-preserved fossil was excavated from a steep hill on inhospitable terrain near Chile's Torres del Paine national park.", "Stegouros translates to \"roofed tail\" while elengassen references a local native people's mythical armoured monster.", "", "
Stegouros lived alongside\u00a0turtles, frogs and small mammals by the banks of rivers.(Reuters:\u00a0Fundacion Azara)
", "While northern hemisphere ankylosaurs are well understood based on numerous fossils, the anatomy of those from the southern hemisphere had remained mysterious owing to remains that are either fragmentary or not yet thoroughly studied.", "Stegouros retained certain traits of the earlier stegosaurs, indicating that southern hemisphere ankylosaurs diverged from their northern cousins early in the ankylosaur lineage's evolution, Mr Soto said.", "Mr Soto called Stegouros the \"Rosetta Stone\" of southern hemisphere ankylosaurs because it had\u00a0enabled scientists to decipher their anatomy for the first time.", "Reuters"]
